page.title: List of artistic depictions of Steve Jobs

revision.text:
[[Steve Jobs]] ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|dʒ|ɒ|b|z}}; February 24, 1955 – October 5, 2011) was an American pioneer of the [[Microcomputer revolution|personal computer revolution of the 1970s]] (along with engineer, inventor, and [[Apple Computer]] co-founder, [[Steve Wozniak]]). Shortly after his death, Jobs's official biographer, [[Walter Isaacson]], described him as the "creative entrepreneur whose passion for perfection and ferocious drive revolutionized six industries: personal computers, animated movies, music, phones, tablet computing, and digital publishing."<ref name="JobsBio1">{{cite book|last=Isaacson|first=Walter | authorlink =Walter Isaacson|title=[[Steve Jobs (book)|Steve Jobs]]|year=2011|isbn= |page=ebook|publisher=Simon & Schuster}}</ref>
== Books ==
=== Autobiographies/memoirs === *2018: ''[[Small Fry (book)|Small Fry]]'' by [[Lisa Brennan-Jobs]] *2014: ''Steve Jobs: The Unauthorized Autobiography'' by J. T. Owens *2013: ''[[The Bite in the Apple]]: A Memoir of My Life with Steve Jobs'' by [[Chrisann Brennan]] *2006: ''[[iWoz]]'' by [[Steve Wozniak]]
=== Biographies and histories === *2015: ''[[Becoming Steve Jobs]]'' by Brent Schlender and Rick Tetzeli *2015: ''Steve Jobs and Philosophy: For Those Who Think Different'', edited by Shawn E. Klein<ref>{{Cite book|title = Steve Jobs and Philosophy: For Those Who Think Different|last = |first = |publisher = Open Court|year = 2015|isbn = 978-0-8126-9889-3|location = Chicago, IL|pages = |editor-last = Klein|editor-first = Shawn}}</ref> *2014: ''[[Creativity, Inc.]]: Overcoming the Unseen Forces That Stand in the Way of True Inspiration'' by [[Edwin Catmull]] of [[Pixar]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ecorner.stanford.edu/authorMaterialInfo.html?mid=3321|title=Stanford's Entrepreneurship Corner: Ed Catmull, Disney/Pixar Animation – Creativity, Inc. [Entire Talk]|work=stanford.edu|access-date=2015-04-11|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160104200227/http://ecorner.stanford.edu/authorMaterialInfo.html?mid=3321|archive-date=2016-01-04|url-status=dead}}</ref> *2011: ''[[Steve Jobs (book)|Steve Jobs]]'' by [[Walter Isaacson]] (the basis for the 2015 film, ''[[Steve Jobs (film)|Steve Jobs]]'' by [[Danny Boyle]]) *2005: ''[[iCon: Steve Jobs]]'' by Jeffrey S. Young & William L. Simon. *2005: ''[[What the Dormouse Said]]: How the 60s Counterculture Shaped the Personal Computer Industry'' by [[John Markoff]] *2004: ''[[Revolution in the Valley]]: The Insanely Great Story of How the Mac was Made'' by [[Andy Hertzfeld]] <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.folklore.org/StoryView.py?story=Revolution_in_the_Valley.txt|title=Folklore.org: Revolution in the Valley|work=folklore.org}}</ref> *2000: ''[[The Second Coming of Steve Jobs]]'' by Alan Deutschman. *1994: ''Insanely Great: The Life and Times of Macintosh, the Computer That Changed Everything'' by [[Steven Levy]] <ref>{{Cite book|isbn=9780670852444|title=INSANELY GREAT: The Life and Times of Macintosh, the Computer that Changed Everything: Steven Levy: Amazon.com: Books|work=amazon.com}}</ref> *1993: ''Steve Jobs & the NeXT Big Thing'' by Randall E. Stross<ref>{{Cite book|isbn=9780689121357|title=Steve Jobs & the Next Big Thing: Randall E. Stross: Amazon.com: Books|work=amazon.com|url=https://archive.org/details/isbn_9780689121357}}</ref> *1992/1996: ''[[Accidental Empires]]'' by [[Robert X. Cringely]] (the basis for the 1996 [[PBS]] documentary, ''[[Triumph of the Nerds]]'') *1988: ''Steve Jobs: The Journey Is the Reward'' by Jeffrey S. Young<ref>{{Cite book|isbn=9781558023789|title=Steve Jobs, the Journey Is the Reward: Jeffrey S. Young: Amazon.com: Books|work=amazon.com}}</ref> *1988: ''Accidental millionaire : the rise and fall of Steve Jobs at Apple Computer'' by Lee Butcher. *1984: ''Fire in the Valley: The Making of the Personal Computer'' by Michael Swaine and Paul Frieberger<ref name=first>{{Cite book|isbn=9780881341218|title=Fire in the Valley: The Making of the Personal Computer: Paul Freiberger, Michael Swaine: Amazon.com: Books|work=amazon.com}}</ref> (''Fire in the Valley: The Making of the Personal Computer,'' second edition, 2000<ref name=second>{{Cite book|isbn=9780071358927|title=Fire in the Valley: The Making of The Personal Computer (Second Edition): Paul Freiberger, Michael Swaine: Amazon.com: Books|work=amazon.com|url=https://archive.org/details/fireinvalleymaki00frei_0}}</ref> and ''Fire in the Valley: The Birth and Death of the Personal Computer,'' third edition, 2014;<ref name=third /> the basis for the 1999 film, ''[[Pirates of Silicon Valley]]'' by [[Martyn Burke]]).<ref name=third>{{cite web|url=http://www.paulfreiberger.com/book/fire-valley-making-personal-computer/|title=Fire in the Valley: The Making of the Personal Computer|date=23 February 2014|work=Paul Freiberger – Author of When Can You Start?}}</ref> *1984: ''[[The Little Kingdom]]:The Private Story of Apple Computer'' by [[Michael Moritz]] (the first history of [[Apple Computer]], updated and reissued as ''[[The Little Kingdom|Return to the Little Kingdom: Steve Jobs and the Creation of Apple]]'' in 2009) *1984: ''[[Hackers: Heroes of the Computer Revolution]]'' by [[Steven Levy]]
=== Graphic novels === *2015: ''Steve Jobs: Insanely Great'' by Jessie Harland.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.penguinrandomhouse.com/books/221297/steve-jobs-insanely-great-by-jessie-hartland/|title=Steve Jobs: Insanely Great|work=PenguinRandomhouse.com}}</ref> *2012: ''The Zen of Steve Jobs'' by Caleb Melby with artwork by Jess3 that explores the relationship between Jobs and [[Kobun Chino Otogawa]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archive.wired.com/geekdad/2012/02/the-zen-of-steve-jobs/|title=Meditations on The Zen of Steve Jobs|work=GeekDad}}</ref> *2012: ''Steve Jobs: Genius by Design'' a biographical graphic work by Jason Quinn (published by Campfire Graphic Novels)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.penguinrandomhouse.com/books/221696/steve-jobs-genius-by-design-by-jason-quinn-amit-tayal/|title=Steve Jobs: Genius by Design|work=PenguinRandomhouse.com}}</ref>
== Films ==
=== Documentaries === *2015: ''Steve Jobs vs. [[Bill Gates]]: The Competition to Control the Personal Computer, 1974–1999'': Original film from the [[National Geographic Channel]] for the ''[[American Genius]]'' series.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://americangenius.nationalgeographic.com/episode/jobs-vs-gates/|title=American Genius|work=American Genius|access-date=2015-05-29|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150910170511/http://americangenius.nationalgeographic.com/episode/jobs-vs-gates|archive-date=2015-09-10|url-status=dead}}</ref> *2015: ''[[Steve Jobs: The Man in the Machine]],'' directed by [[Alex Gibney]]. *2012 (1995): ''[[Steve Jobs: The Lost Interview]],'' directed by Paul Sen, written and narrated by [[Robert X. Cringely]]. The film includes the full 70-minute interview Jobs gave to Cringely for ''[[Triumph of the Nerds]]'' in 1995. *2011: ''[[Steve Jobs: Billion Dollar Hippy]]'', a 2011 documentary TV film produced by [[BBC]].<ref>[[IMDbTitle:2132457|Billion Dollar Hippie]]</ref> *2011: ''[[Steve Jobs: One Last Thing]]'', a documentary film produced by [[PBS]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/programs/steve-jobs-one-last-thing |title=Steve Jobs: One Last Thing PBS show website |publisher=Pbs.org |date=October 5, 2011 |accessdate=November 12, 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/68egFJeKO?url=http://www.pbs.org/programs/steve-jobs-one-last-thing |archivedate=June 24, 2012 |url-status=live }}</ref> A slightly shortened and localized<ref>The narrator in the UK version of the show has a British accent, for the purpose of catering to the local market.</ref> version of the show was broadcast<ref>{{cite web|last=Truta|first=Filip|title='Steve Jobs: iChanged the World' Documentary Airs Tonight in the UK|url=http://news.softpedia.com/news/Steve-Jobs-iChanged-the-World-Documentary-Airs-Tonight-in-the-UK-232019.shtml|publisher=[[Softpedia]]|accessdate=December 2, 2011 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140410022730/http://news.softpedia.com/news/Steve-Jobs-iChanged-the-World-Documentary-Airs-Tonight-in-the-UK-232019.shtml | archivedate = 2014-04-10| url-status=live}}</ref> in the United Kingdom the following day titled, ''Steve Jobs: iChanged the World''{{spaced ndash}} on [[Channel 4]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.channel4.com/programmes/steve-jobs-ichanged-the-world/4od |title=Steve Jobs: iChanged the World |publisher=http://www.channel4.com |accessdate=November 15, 2011 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20131020011230/http://www.channel4.com/programmes/steve-jobs-ichanged-the-world/4od | archivedate = 2013-10-20| url-status=live}}</ref> *2011: ''iGenius: How Steve Jobs Changed the World'': a [[Discovery Channel]] documentary hosted by [[Adam Savage]] and [[Jamie Hyneman]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/steve-jobs-documentary-on-discovery-246273 |title='iGenius: How Steve Jobs Changed the World' Airs Sunday on Discovery |work=The Hollywood Reporter |date= October 10, 2011|accessdate=February 8, 2015 |first=Jethro |last=Nede | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20131231084755/http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/steve-jobs-documentary-on-discovery-246273 | archivedate = 2013-12-31| url-status=live}}</ref> *2001: ''[[Golden Dreams]]'': a short film about the [[history of California]] shown at [[Disney California Adventure Park]]. Jobs is portrayed by [[Mark Neveldine]]. *1996: ''[[Triumph of the Nerds]]'': directed by Paul Sen, written and narrated by Robert X. Cringely. The film contains clips of interviews with Jobs conducted by Cringely in 1995. *1992: ''[[The Machine That Changed the World (TV miniseries)|The Machine That Changed the World]]'': Part 3 of this five-part documentary, called ''The Paperback Computer'', prominently featured Jobs and his role in the early days of Apple.
=== Feature films === *2015: ''[[Steve Jobs (film)|Steve Jobs]]'': a [[feature film]] directed by [[Danny Boyle]], with a screenplay by [[Aaron Sorkin]]. Jobs is portrayed by [[Michael Fassbender]]. *2013: ''[[Jobs (film)|Jobs]]'': an [[independent film]] directed by [[Joshua Michael Stern]]. Jobs is portrayed by [[Ashton Kutcher]]. *2013: ''[[iSteve]]'': a satirical film directed by [[Ryan Perez]] in which Jobs is portrayed by [[Justin Long]]. *1999: ''[[Pirates of Silicon Valley]]'': a [[TNT (U.S. TV network)|TNT]] film directed by [[Martyn Burke]]. Jobs is portrayed by [[Noah Wyle]].
== Theater and opera == *2018: ''Plague'' – transmediale festival, composed by [[James Ferraro]]. *2017: ''[[The (R)evolution of Steve Jobs]]'' – [[Santa Fe Opera]], composed by [[Mason Bates]] with libretto by [[Mark Campbell (librettist)|Mark Campbell]].<ref name="guardian2017-07-23">{{cite news | title='Nobody has one button': Steve Jobs opera sings Apple founder's praises – and flaws | url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2017/jul/23/revolution-of-steve-jobs-opera-sante-fe | first=Chloe | last=Veltman | work=[[The Guardian]] | date=July 23, 2017 | access-date=2017-07-23 }} </ref> *2012: ''The Agony and Ecstasy of Steve Jobs'' – [[The Public Theater]], New York City, created and performed by [[Mike Daisey]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.publictheater.org/component/option%2ccom_shows/task%2cview/Itemid%2c141/id%2c1043 | title=The Agony and Ecstasy of Steve Jobs | work=publictheater.org | date=March 2012 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140107085326/http://www.publictheater.org/component/option%2Ccom_shows/task%2Cview/Itemid%2C141/id%2C1043 | archivedate=2014-01-07 | url-status=dead }} </ref>
== Video and games == *2018: ''Over My Dead Body'' (subject of interview on [[Amazon Prime]] TV comedy series)<ref>https://www.amazon.com/Steve-Jobs-Reboot/dp/B078WYJHJ9/ref=sr_1_19?ie=UTF8&qid=1515598813&sr=8-19&keywords=over+my+dead+body</ref> *1999: [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TIClAanU7Os Noah Wyle and Steve Jobs at the 1999 Macworld NY (video clip)] (references the 1999 film, ''[[Pirates of Silicon Valley]]'' starring [[Noah Wyle]] as Jobs) *1997: [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=E2qxVhP46Yk Early version of Apple's "Think Different" ad] – ''[[Think different]]'' narrated by Jobs but never released on television *His '80s appearance was referenced in the 2017 video game Computer Tycoon, however he sports a blonde haircut rather than his black haircut.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/686680/Computer_Tycoon/|title=Computer Tycoon on Steam|website=store.steampowered.com|language=en|access-date=2020-03-29}}</ref>
== Painting == *2015: ''[[The Son of a Migrant from Syria]]'', a mural near [[Calais]], France, by street artist [[Banksy]]<ref name=banksy>{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-35076976 | title=Banksy work in Calais 'Jungle' shows Steve Jobs as migrant | publisher=[[BBC News]] | date=11 December 2015 | accessdate=12 December 2015}}</ref> == Statue == Statue of Jobs at Graphisoft Park, Budapest
== Audio == *2016–: ''[[The Aunty Donna Podcast]]'', in which Broden Kelly portrays Steve Gobs, a character similar to Jobs who, instead of being the mastermind behind Apple products, enjoys {{clarify span|date=October 2018|giving people gobbies}}.
== References == {{reflist|30em}}
== External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20170222204258/http://www.imdb.com/character/ch0028580/ Steve Jobs (Character)] on [[IMDb]] * {{imdb name|423418|Steve Jobs (1955–2011)}} *"[http://fortune.com/2011/10/07/noah-wyle-on-playing-steve-jobs/ Noah Wyle on playing Steve Jobs]" (in the 1999 film, ''[[Pirates of Silicon Valley]]''), ''[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]].'' October 7, 2011.
{{Steve Jobs|state=expanded}} {{Apple}}
